en.value: I'm going on vacation!
Talking about travel plans - Future forms
When's your next holiday?

Most people love planning trips and telling their friends where they're going to go next and what they'll do there. In this lesson we'll talk about planning different types of holidays.
Fun fact before we start: in the UK, we say "holiday", whereas in the USA, it's "vacation".
I can't wait to get away for a couple of weeks.
We're looking forward to our city trip, even though we both prefer the outdoors.
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
can't wait to
I can't wait to go to South America next month!
True or false?
I can't wait to go on vacation next week!
This person is looking forward to their upcoming trip.
can't wait for
I bet you can't wait for your holiday.
Select the words in the correct order.
[k]I[/k] [k]can't[/k] [k]wait[/k] [k]for[/k] [k]our[/k] [k]holiday![/k]
Here's a tip!

We can use "can't wait to" and "can't wait for" when we are excited for something to happen in the future. The only difference between the two is that we follow "can't wait to" with a verb and "can't wait for" with a noun.
I can't wait to go to South America next month!
I bet you can't wait for your holiday.
Match the beginning and end of each sentence.
I can't wait to
I can't wait for
visit my friends in Portugal.
my trip to Portugal.
[k]He[/k] [k]can't[/k] [k]wait[/k] [k]to[/k] [k]go[/k] [k]to India.[/k]
to get away
I can't wait to get away for a couple of weeks.
getaway
We're planning a romantic getaway to the south of France.
Match the beginning and end of each sentence.
I bet you're excited for your holiday. It'll be so nice to
It's been a busy few months. I think we need a
get away from it all for a while.
getaway soon.
Did you notice?
"To get away" also has a noun form: "a getaway". This is a particular type of phrasal verb, which can become a phrasal noun. There are a fair few of these in English. Here are some other useful ones:
to meet up - a meetup
to mix up - a mix-up
to look about - a lookabout
city break
We enjoyed our city break, but we both prefer the outdoors.
beach holiday
We might go on a beach holiday this winter, for some winter sun.
laid-back
I think I may want a more laid-back holiday this time.
Here are some useful words and phrases for describing types of holiday:
Active holidays are great if you enjoy the outdoors.
We're going all-inclusive when we go to Egypt.
budget
active
mini break
Select the type of holiday you'd most likely go on if you love the outdoors.
active holiday
short city trip
romantic getaway
Select the type of holiday you'd most likely go on to spend quality time with your partner.
romantic getaway
budget holiday
mini break
to find your way around
It's really easy to find your way around.
to get in contact with someone
I'm going to get in contact with our host and ask her what time the bus leaves.
[k]Why don't you[/k] [k]get[/k] [k]in[/k] [k]contact[/k] [k]with[/k] [k]the hotel[/k] [k]and ask them[/k] [k]if they provide towels.[/k]

It's also very common to say "to get in touch with someone". It means the same as "to get in contact with someone" and the two are interchangeable. We can also simply say "to call someone" or "to email someone" to be more specific.
Could you get in touch with the airline to ask about baggage allowance?
I'll email the hotel to ask about checkin times.
Are you going to call the taxi company to ask if they found your purse?
They can't afford an expensive luxury holiday.
What is this person saying?
They usually prefer to go on a budget holiday.
They think it's best if they go on an all-inclusive holiday.
Match each type of holiday with its description.
all-inclusive holiday
budget holiday
laid-back holiday
when the price that you pay covers all costs, including food and drink
when you pay less for a holiday and settle for a less luxury experience
when you plan on mostly relaxing while you're on holiday
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
You should get in [k]touch[/k] with the hotel.
call
They will pay one price which covers their accommodation, food and drinks.
They will pay for their accommodation but will have to cook their own meals.
They will pay for their accommodation but will buy food from the hotel restaurant.
I can't wait [k]to get away[/k] for a week.
a getaway
We might book a mini break next month.
This person is definitely going to book a short break next month.
The word "might" implies the possibility of something, but not a definite plan.
They want to spend some time relaxing on their holiday.
They have a packed schedule for their next holiday.
They plan on being very active while they're on holiday.
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
I can't wait to [k]sit[/k] by a pool and to [k]do[/k] nothing for a week.
sitting
doing
[k]I will[/k] [k]get[/k] [k]in[/k] [k]touch[/k] [k]with[/k] [k]our host[/k] [k]to ask[/k] [k]about parking.[/k]
I'll [k]email[/k] the hotel to ask about checkin times.
send an email
Fill in the gap using the audio.
It might be better if we go [k]all-inclusive[/k].
It's really easy [k]to find[/k] your [k]way[/k] around.
find
why
We're going on a [k]city trip[/k] to Milan next weekend.
If we want to go away this year, it'll have to be a [k]budget[/k] holiday.
[k]I can't[/k] [k]wait[/k] [k]for[/k] [k]a[/k] [k]laid-[/k] [k]back[/k] [k]holiday[/k] [k]this summer.[/k]
They're going on a romantic [k]getaway[/k] to the south of Spain.
Fill in the gap using the hint.
You should [k]get in contact with|call|email|contact[/k] the hostel.
Another way of saying "to get in touch with".
I'm planning a trip.
You are going to listen to two friends, Priya and Dean, have a conversation about a trip. What sort of trip does Priya want?
Let's listen!
Priya's Getaway, Part One
Priya and Dean plan a trip together.
What sort of trip does Priya want to take?
a relaxing trip somewhere calm
a luxury beach trip at a resort
a cultural trip to visit ruins and museums
Listen to the audio clip.
Priya is looking forward to being somewhere quiet.
She wants to get away from people.
Which city did Priya decide to visit?
Asunción [h]Bariloche[/h] Bogotá Brasilia Lima Santiago
Listen to the audio clip. Which of these statements best describes the flight Priya is planning to take.
The flight is cheaper than usual.
The flight is more expensive than usual.
The flight is the same price as usual.
Listen to the audio clip. What are Priya and Dean using to research this trip?
an online map
a travel guide
a Spanish textbook
How much does Dean know about Bariloche?
nothing
a little
a lot
Yes, look, there's a small city next to [k]a lake[/k] in the mountains. Oh, this looks perfect!
What is the detail that convinces Priya to go to Bariloche?
She wants to visit the chocolate museum.
She wants to go swimming in the lake.
She wants to practice her Spanish.
Listen to the audio clip.
Priya is looking forward to taking her trip with Dean.
She wants to be alone, she's just being polite.
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
Listen to the conversation between Priya and Dean one last time with the text. Look for any words or phrases you didn't understand before.
Hey Priya, how are you?
Good, thanks!
Really? You look distracted.
Oh, I'm looking at this email with [k]budget[/k] flights to South America.
Oh cool, do you want to go on a holiday?
Yeah, I had a hard time at work the last two months, so I think I'm going to [k]get away[/k] and relax a bit.
That sounds good, what sort of trip do you want? Are you going to lie in the sun at an [k]all-inclusive[/k] beach resort?
No, nothing like that. I think I will go somewhere less touristy. I want to avoid people! Maybe I'll go somewhere I can walk around and enjoy the [k]scenery[/k] and just get away from it all.
Do you think you will go to a city then - to walk around and go to museums, parks, things like that?

Hmmm, no, that's still too many people for what I want. Maybe somewhere smaller, and close to nature. I'm thinking I'll go to a smaller city that is near some nature trails or [k]hiking paths[/k]. What do you think of the options on this email?

Hmmmm, let's see.... Asuncion, Bariloche ... Bogota and Buenos Aires are going to be too big ... oh, what about Lima? I hear that's a nice city, and you could go hiking in the Andes and see the old Incan ruins, Machu Picchu, from there!

That sounds nice, but no. Look at this map, Lima is the [k]capital[/k] city so it'll probably be really crowded, and anyway it's pretty far from Machu Picchu. I'm going to see Machu Picchu one day, but I want to avoid tourist hotspots for this trip. I wonder where some of these other cities are on the map.
Yeah, I never heard of Bariloche before.
I think it's pronounced Bariloche in Spanish. Oh look it's here in [k]southern[/k] Argentina!
Can you zoom in a little? It doesn't look like there's much there.
Yes, look, there's a small city next to a lake in the mountains. Oh, this looks [k]perfect[/k]!
Yeah, wow, look at those pictures. That looks [k]gorgeous[/k].
And look, there's a chocolate museum in the town. That's all I need, I'm going to go there!
Wow, yeah, maybe I'll join you!
Yeah, [k]maybe[/k].
Dean
Priya
Now you will listen to Priya plan the specifics of her holiday with her friend Juliana. Does Priya know what she will do in Bariloche?
Priya and Juliana talk about the details of Priya's trip.
Priya's Getaway, Part Two
Listen to the audio clip.
Priya has planned her trip already.
Priya has read a lot about Bariloche, but hasn't decided what to do yet.
Did you notice?

Juliana says on vacation, but earlier Dean said on holiday. This is because of regional differences in English. People whose English is more influenced by British English tend to say "on holiday" while people whose English is influenced more by American English will say "on vacation". These two phrases mean the same thing.
Many Canadians go on vacation to Florida.
People from Hong Kong often go on holiday to Singapore.
Juliana is from [k]Brazil[/k].
Argentina
How long is Priya's trip?
a little longer than one week
one week exactly
a little shorter than a week
How much does Juliana know about Bariloche?
a lot
a little
nothing
Which three things will Priya definitely do in Bariloche?
skiing, [h]hiking[/h], kayaking, horseback-riding, [h]cruise[/h], [h]zipline[/h]
Listen to the conversation between Priya and Juliana one last time with the text. Look for any words or phrases you didn't understand before.
Hey Priya!
Oh, hi Juliana!
Dean told me you are going to Argentina, that's amazing!
Yes, I need a break, and this town looks [k]incredible[/k]. Wait, you're from Brazil aren't you? Have you been to Bariloche?
I love Bariloche, my family used to go skiing there. Lots of Brazilians go on [k]vacation[/k] in Argentina.
Really? Tell me everything! I looked at lots of travel websites, but I'm still not sure what to do. I am going to decide when I get there.
Ooh, exciting! How long will you be there?
I'm going for [k]just over[/k] a week. My flight leaves Friday night, and I am going to fly home on the following Sunday.
That's great! I'll pick you up from the airport when you get back if you want! Well, the mountains are beautiful. Are you going to go skiing, or hiking around?
Definitely hiking, that's the one thing I know for sure I'm going to do. I want to go on a hike through Paso de las Nubes. Do you think I should [k]book[/k] a tour, or go alone?
Definitely book a tour! It will take you two days to do that hike, so you'll need someone to organise it for you.
Oh wow, ok, I'll book those tickets tonight then! What else is there to do there?
Well, I know that you can go kayaking on the lake, go [k]horseback[/k] riding, take a boat cruise on the lakes, and I think there is a zipline park.

Well, I'm [k]terrified[/k] of horses, so I won't be doing that! Kayaking sounds like it might be fun if the weather is nice, I'll think about it. I love ziplines though, it feels like [k]flying[/k]. I will look for that park for sure.
It sounds like you'll be quite active!
Yeah, but the boat cruise also sounds good. I'll book tickets on one of those. I'm going to want a day of [k]rest[/k] after hiking I think.
Definitely, I'm so jealous! You're [k]going[/k] to take lots of photos to show me, right?
[k]I will[/k], thanks so much for your help!
Of course! Have fun!
Juliana
Grammar: future forms
As you know, we use will and be going to when talking about the future. Here's a quick recap on how to use them:
will + verb
I <u>will</u> <u>send</u> you a postcard.
This trip won't be cheap. (In informal contexts, "will not" becomes "won't")
What time <u>will</u> the museum <u>open</u>?
be going to + verb
I<u>'m going to</u> <u>go</u> to Argentina next month.
She<u>'s not going to</u> <u>visit</u> Peru this time.
What <u>are</u> you <u>going to</u> <u>do</u>?
Select the future forms in these sentences.
The host [h]is[/h] [h]going[/h] [h]to[/h] email us the directions.
Good, I [h]will[/h] print them.
will vs. be going to
We can use either will or be going to in most contexts. Choosing one or the other doesn't usually affect meaning, but if you want to sound more fluent you should be aware of these points:
1. For prior plans, or events that are just about to happen, use be going to.
2. For quick decisions you make while speaking, use will.
3. For predictions, you can use either will or be going to - it doesn't matter!
These examples show how we use will and be going to:
Prior plan: I am going to fly home on Sunday.
Quick decision: Great, I will pick you up from the airport.
About to happen: I should say goodbye now. My phone is going to run out of battery.
Prediction: Take care! I'm sure you will have a great time. / Take care! I'm sure you are going to have a great time.
That bag looks heavy. I'll help you.
The speaker had plans to help before seeing the bag.
The speaker saw the bag and made a quick decision to help.
[k]We[/k] [k]are going to[/k] [k]go on a city break[/k] [k]next month.[/k]
Select the best response to this statement: "Look, here comes your suitcase!"
I'll get it!
I'm going to get it!
I get it!

Don't worry if you mix up will and be going to - people will still understand you. The important thing is knowing how the two forms fit into sentences - for example, using the correct form of "be". Let's practise!
What [k]are[/k] you [k]going[/k] to do this weekend?
is
go
My friend and I [k]are going to[/k] go to the night market on Saturday.
am going to
I think the food in Argentina [k]will[/k] be spicy.
going to
Have you seen the weather forecast? It's [k]going to[/k] rain heavily tomorrow.
will
The school trip was really fun. I [k]will[/k] show you some photos later.
am going
Here's a summary!
This table summarises what we've just learned:
will
quick decisions
be going to
prior plans; events that are about to happen
will or be going to
predictions
When we have confirmed plans, we often use the present continuous instead of be going to. Check out the following examples:
I am going to go on a trip tomorrow. → I am going on a trip tomorrow.
They are going to move house soon. → They are moving house soon.
He's not going to join us for dinner. → He's not joining us for dinner.
A: What are you [k]doing[/k] next weekend?
do
[k]I'm[/k] [k]visiting[/k] [k]friends in Istanbul[/k] [k]next[/k] [k]weekend.[/k]
We have seen three ways to talk about the future. Check out the summary below, then continue practising!
will
I <u>will book</u> the tickets tonight.
be going to
I'm <u>going to book</u> the tickets tonight.
present continuous
I<u>'m booking</u> the tickets tonight.
Are you [k]going to[/k] go somewhere nice this summer?
will
We're [k]going to[/k] Thailand for two weeks in August.
going
You book the flights and I'll [k]book[/k] the hotel.
booking
Match the pairs of words / phrases.
I
She
We
am going to go on vacation.
is going to go on vacation.
are going to go on vacation.
Select the statement which is not grammatically correct.
Put your seatbelt on, we will landing soon.
Put your seatbelt on, we're going to land soon.
Put your seatbelt on, we're landing soon.
The staff were nice but the rooms were small and dirty - we [k]won't[/k] stay there again.
don't
Type the missing words, using she and be going to.
It's New Year next week so [k]she's going to|she is going to[/k] visit her relatives.
In informal situations, going to is often pronounced as gonna. It's safe to use gonna in casual conversations or text messages with friends, but it should be avoided in formal writing!
I'm going to miss you! → I'm gonna miss you!
She's going to try the local food. → She's gonna try the local food.
We're [k]gonna[/k] order pizza later. Text me back if you want in!
will
Match the phrases with their casual forms.
I'm going to be late.
I will be late.
I will not be late.
I'm gonna be late.
I'll be late.
I won't be late.
Midday on Saturday? Great, [k]we'll[/k] meet you at the station.
Type the missing words, using I and be going to.
[k]I'm going to|I am going to|I'm gonna|I am gonna[/k] fly home on Sunday.
Select the most suitable response to this question: "Got any plans for your day off?"
Not really, I'm just going to relax.
Good idea, I'll come with you.
I'm going to take the day off.
Type the missing words, using the verb depart and a suitable future form.
The flight [k]will depart|is going to depart|is departing[/k] in one hour, sir.
Type the missing words, using the words and image as hints.
[k]The sun will|The sun is going to|The sun's going to[/k] rise at 6 a.m. tomorrow.
I'm [k]going to go|going[/k] on a trip next weekend. Could you feed my cat, please?
